repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Emergency Agricultural
            Productivity Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Agricultural
            Productivity Support Project for Guinea were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and grantee performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: strong
            involvement of producer organizations in project
            implementation is a key factor for success on the ground.
            Innovative solutions enable project implementation to
            continue in a context of political instability and social
            unrest. The project lost momentum because seed was not
            delivered on time for planting. Procurement of seed and
            fertilizer was delayed, and the government lost the proceeds
            of the grant. Such circumstances demanded innovative
            mechanisms to help the project stay afloat. Capable producer
            organizations may be a good entry point for a sustainable
            input distribution mechanism. Capacity building is essential
            for public entities to fully match their capabilities to
            their responsibilities in project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Emergency Agricultural
            Productivity Support Project : pest management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objective is to increase
            rice productivity by 30 percent by the provision of small
            farmers of improved seeds, fertilizers and herbicides to sow
            a total area of 35,000 hectares and therefore increase
            production of 70,000 tons, equivalent to 10 percent of total
            production, the incomes of small farmers and the
            availability of locally grown rice. This suggests that
            environmental and social impacts of the project, for the
            most part, will be minimal, site-specific and manageable to
            an accepted level. Part of the implementation activities of
            PUAPA, in terms of pest management and pesticide is designed
            to minimize the potential negative effects on human and
            animal health and the environment which may arise in
            particular as part of vector control, and to promote
            integrated pest management. The main risks, in the case of
            conventional pesticides are: ground surface water, water
            wells, air, biodiversity and human health.
